data.title: Cursor is not between comment tags when toggling line comment with start/end components
data.body:
## Problem

When you use the shortcut for comments in a CSS file, your cursor should be placed between the two comment tags. Currently it is placed _after_ the comment tags, which forces the user to go back two characters with the left arrow.

![capture d ecran 2014-12-28 a 10 33 20](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4740645/5563535/073e1900-8e7d-11e4-851c-b46e92df18bf.png)
## Steps to reproduce

Just hit Cmd-Shift-: in a CSS file.
## Config

Atom version 0.165.0
Mac OS X version 10.10.2.

data.title: Update scroll position when opening from command line with line specified
data.body:
Attempt to fix #4780.  

The event listener solution is probably hacky.  I mostly don't quite know when the DisplayBuffer is fully "initialized"/has a height, width, etc.  As of right now if I attempt to call @scrollToCursorPosition() in TextEditor's constructor (at say line 105), the DisplayBuffer has no size information when it gets to scrollToScreenRange() and no scrolling occurs.

data.title: Scroll isn't updated when using a line number from the command line
data.body:
Currently when you open a file from the command line with a line number, i.e.:

```
atom ~/cool-thing.js:42
```

there is a cursor set, but the editor is still scrolled to the top.  Ideally the editor should open up scrolled to the location of the cursor.

data.title: Fix typo in WorkspaceView deprecation
data.body: TextEditor::onDidAddTextEditor doesn't exist.  Assuming Workspace::onDidAddTextEditor was intended.

data.title: Tabbing in a Sass Map sometimes causes error
data.body:
Alright, I've tried but cannot seem to recreate the cause of this issue, but it occurs fairly regularly.

When working in Sass files if I try to tab indent a line within a map I sometimes get an error.

Error:
`Uncaught TypeError: Cannot read property 'shift' of undefined c:\ProgramData\chocolatey\lib-bad\Atom.0.150.0\tools\Atom\resources\app\node_modules\text-buffer\lib\history.js:109`

Sample Code:

``` css
$my_map: (
  a_key: a_value
);
```

---
### System Specs

Windows 8.1
Node 0.10.26
Atom 0.150.0

data.title: Can't paste file path in the open dialog with Cmd+G
data.body:
Latest Atom build (.165.0) on OS X Yosamite (v. 10.10.1) won't allow for pasting into the file-path in the open dialog after hitting Cmd+G.  Open dialogues in other programs on OS X appear to allow this, which makes me think Atom is messing up.

Seems like everyone here posts a Console.log message - here's the message.  This stuff only happens when Atom starts, not during the disallowed paste behavior. 

```
2014-12-27 12:59:48.630 PM Atom[870]: App load time: 270ms
2014-12-27 12:59:54.265 PM Atom[870]: assertion failed: 14B25: libxpc.dylib + 97940 [9437C02E-A07B-38C8-91CB-299FAA63083D]: 0x89
```

data.title: Atom's package.json should support other npm-style repository formats
data.body:
For example, [atom-jshint](https://github.com/sindresorhus/atom-jshint) has `repository` set to `sindresorhus/atom-jshint` in its `package.json`, which should be fine, but Atom seems to default to `git://` when rendering package links.

![screenshot 2014-12-27 16 04 27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/471278/5561594/3ae6e12e-8de2-11e4-874f-2320be9ffcd3.png)

data.title: please add a "recent directories" item to the File menu
data.body: I find it annoying I have to open a shell and run `atom` to get to my recent directories.

data.title: Deprecate `Config::addScopedProperties`
data.body:
Use `::set` instead.

This drove out fixing some things about `Config::set`:
- With a null key-path, it now sets the root object
- `::unset` now works with a `source` but no `scopeSelector`
- `editor.completions` now needs to be part of the built-in schema, because many packages write to that key-path as a scoped property.

data.title: Add option(s) to forget parts of window/project state
data.body:
Right now Atom stores off (near?) complete state on exit, so when opening it will restore everything back to how it was. This is nice for some people and some aspects of the editor, but I personally don't want to have all that state stored. For one, I like a clean start when sitting down to work so having the tree view remember all the folders that were open or having all previously open files pop up isn't helpful to me. Additionally I'd bet that having it reopen a bunch of files is adding extra startup time which, since I don't want those files open anyway, is another negative side-effect.

If there are already unexposed settings for this, let me know and I'll just add them to my config. :)

Or if someone can point me in the right direction I can see about implementing these settings myself. I'd just need a couple pointers on how to work with the config and where the functionality in question would be found in the source code. 

Ideally the option(s) would apply both proactively (i.e. when enabled, don't even write the given state to disk) and retroactively (i.e. when enabled, clear applicable state on load). That way there's no wasted time saving state the user chooses to ignore, but if the user already had save state, it gets ignored on the next launch.

data.title: Uncaught TypeError: Unable to watch path

data.title: sometimes atom resets the config.cson
data.body:
Copied from [here](https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/4721#issuecomment-68152049):
That happened a couple of times while working on the currently selected theme in atom. Every couple of theme reloads (after saving one of the less files) I was left with a newly initialized config file.

I noticed this because I deactivated the welcome package and every time the config file is reset the welcome screen opens in all instances and the theme switches to atom dark.

Once one of the instances initialized a new config file, while another instance overwrote it with the old config file again. Because the welcome page opened but when I looked at the config it was the old one with the deactivated welcome package.

@maxbrunsfeld I don't know if it also happens in safe mode, I didn't work in safe mode and I just tried to reproduce it by changing and saving some less files of the current theme, but without success. Maybe has also to do with one atom window being in debug mode and the other not?

This is the config file it reset mine into:

``` coffeescript
'global':
  'welcome':
    'showOnStartup': false
  'editor': {}
'.js.regexp.source':
  'editor': {}
'.js.source':
  'editor':
    'softWrapAtPreferredLineLength': false
    'softWrap': false
'.gfm.source':
  'editor':
    'softWrap': true
    'softWrapAtPreferredLineLength': false
    'tabLength': 4
  'whitespace':
    'removeTrailingWhitespace': false
'.ini.source':
  'editor': {}
```
## Repro Steps

I don't know how to reproduce this reliably.
## Versions
- **Atom:**       0.166.0-b4b492a
- **Atom-Shell:** 0.19.4
- **OS:**         linux 3.17.4-1-ARCH
- **Misc**
  - apm  0.116.0
  - npm  1.4.4
  - node 0.10.33
  - python 2.7.9
  - git 2.2.1

---

<small>This report was created in and posted from the Atom editor using the package `bug-report` v0.5.3.</small>

data.title: Allow context-targeted user stylesheets
data.body:
Status: This blocks default enabling of the shadow DOM, so getting it out of the way.

Such as `~/.atom/styles.atom-text-editor.less`.

data.title: [syntax] Add proper classes to "finally" keyword
data.body:
The keywords "try" and "catch" get proper classes, but "finally" doesn't.
It needs to get the "keyword.control.exception.finally" classes, but right now gets "constant.other" (in php).

data.title: Resizing Atom to small widths causes CPU load and crashes
data.body:
Just noticed that it's similar to #3999 but I don't have soft wrap enabled.

```
'global':
  'exception-reporting':
    'userId': '84c65616-dd5b-347b-3d53-50153c0eb9a2'
  'welcome':
    'showOnStartup': false
  'core': {}
  'editor':
    'invisibles': {}
  'spell-check': {}

Windows 10 x64 Build 9841
Atom 0.165.0
```

Repro:

1: Open some folder (doesn't work if the directory view thingy on the left isn't open)
2: Resize the width of Atom to like <200px
3: Atom's CPU usage will skyrocket, Atom will notice by itself that it's not responding [1]
4: Atom will notice that the editor has crashed, but you can't press any button [2]

![1](http://i.imgur.com/anCCI4v.png)
![2](http://i.imgur.com/AzPmXFT.png)

Repro video:

https://mediacru.sh/95yH3e-Wv9tQ

Furthermore, `ctrl-alt-p` is bound to the package specs command, which I don’t give a heck. How could I disable that? Thanks!

data.title: Featured packages should hide installed packages to show new ones
data.body: I think this could also apply to themes etc. if there was enough featured content.

data.title: Windows High Contrast Check for Updates
data.body:
The `Help->Check for Update` dialog does not show any text for Windows dark high contrast themes (it actually probably does, just in white). By windows themes, I'm talking about the themes you can get to in windows 8 by, on the desktop, `[right click]->Personalize`. All of the windows 8 built-in high contrast themes, with the exception of "High Contrast White," have this issue. 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4203662/5550707/2f2742e2-8b72-11e4-90f7-47e97ae00560.png)

data.title: Git directory is visible in the sidebar despite being ignored
data.body:
I've left the "Ignored Names" at its default setting, but the `.git` directory in my repositories is displayed in the sidebar on the latest version of Atom:

![](https://cloudup.com/cr7vkcOojE8+)

data.title: Multiple blinking carrots when spamming Control + S
data.body:
I noticed a visual bug when I was using Atom, it may not be of much interest to most people but it is a bug nonetheless.
When spamming Control + S (The save command), if you click on different lines you may notice that there are multiple blinking 'carrots' for each of the lines. It doesn't really have any effect as the last carrot that was created will be used when typing and the others go away, but I thought that I should mention the bug here.
Thanks for taking the time to read this, I'm sure you get a lot of these bug reports.

data.title: Quitting one window == all Atom windows being closed.
data.body:
I discovered today when I did `CTRL`+`Q` on my Ubuntu machine that it closed all the windows, all of which were different folders and entirely different spawns of Atom (or what should have been.)

This a pretty severe bug IMO because it severely inhibits working with the keyboard efficiently.

data.title: Speed up and simplify config file reloading
data.body:
Changing the font size can sometimes be slow because of time spent triggering many events while reloading the config file. This speeds it up.

It used to be necessary to individually set each 'leaf' value in the user's config, to trigger the right events. Now we don't need to do that; event listeners take care of checking for changes in the observed key paths.
